Expectation1: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation1: The mentor assigned a code sample to be finished before the next meeting in three days.
Expectation2: Perform assigned physical tasks and material handling efficiently.
Situation2: A carpenter is waiting for you to bring them the next load of lumber so they can continue their work without interruption.
Story: Sweat trickled down my back as I hoisted another plank of lumber, the sun beating hard on the construction site. The carpenter waved, impatience clear in his stance—he needed the next load now, and I was already behind. My phone buzzed in my pocket, a reminder from my mentor: “Don’t forget to finish the code sample before our meeting.” I pictured the half-written lines of code waiting for me at home, the logic bug I still hadn’t solved. My mentor expected me to be prepared, to show progress and initiative. But here, on the site, the foreman and the crew needed me to keep pace, to keep the workflow moving. I felt pulled in two directions—my mind racing with algorithms while my body strained under the weight of lumber. Each role demanded my full attention, and I could feel the tension building inside me, unsure which expectation I could afford to let down.
